I was deeply moved and inspired by this conversation and it gave me hope that the complex trauma and all the downstream consequences of it could be healed.    I've been to many different therapists and have tried everything out there, but far too often therapists take a few courses and then add "trauma informed" to their list of things they treat and ultimately get in over their head and make things worse.  I reached out to Paul Conti's center up in Portland and was incredibly disappointed to find out that a short residential stay was nearly $25,000!   No one talks about the profound cost of getting quality therapy and far too often the people who need it the most are so dysfunctional they could never afford it and so get shunted to the vast majority of technically qualified, but grossly insufficient therapists out there.  It's really demoralizing.  If you're wealthy and have some psychological boo boos then there are plenty of over paid people who will gladly hand out bandaids and as a bonus be able to make their boat payments.    It is unethical to have such a prohibitive paywall and it is highly problematic that there is little to no oversight in a field that works with highly vulnerable people who have already been screwed over enough.

I was going through a terrible time-i overworked, to distract myself from it. Then everything crashed when i was hospitalised with a prolapsed lumbar disc, which was pinching a spinal nerve root=electrical pain id never wish on anyone. I was put on pregabalin & cocodamol whilst i hobbled to physio appointments -usually with a walking stick but sometimes, crutches (i was in my 40s at the time).  I couldnt work for some time and still in pain, i then also had a breakdown, because all the anxieties/ depression id been trying to run from, came up.  Finally, i spoke to my doc about it and he gave me citalopram, and i sought out counselling. My doc said absolutely not to yoga-my back was still bad-but yes to meditation. So, that got added to the list. I commited to everything and found that the citalopram/meditation/talking therapy, all combined, to bring me to a better place. It felt that was the magical combination, for me. And as i started to feel stronger in myself, i started to lower my own doses of my back meds, too. I pushed myself each day, to walk that little bit further-however slow i was/long it took me. If i had to use a cane or crutches, so be it. And bit by bit, everything worked out.  You learn mental strength from these times in life. Mental fortitude, which i carry with me still.

Agency Agency, often referred to as personal autonomy or self-determination, signifies the capacity to make choices and decisions that reflect our own values and desires. It is the sense that we are in control of our lives and possess the power to shape our destinies. Agency is an integral facet of mental health, empowering individuals to navigate challenges, set and attain goals, and cultivate a robust sense of self. The Significance of Agency The importance of agency in mental health cannot be overstated. When individuals possess a sense of agency, they are more likely to experience: Reduced Stress and Anxiety: Empowerment to make choices and take action in oneâ€™s life can mitigate stress and anxiety. When individuals perceive that they can influence their circumstances, they are better equipped to manage lifeâ€™s inevitable challenges. Enhanced Resilience: Agency fosters resilience, equipping individuals to bounce back from setbacks and adversity. Those who believe they can shape their own destinies are more likely to persevere in the face of difficulties. Elevated Self-Esteem: Agency contributes to a positive self-image. When individuals take ownership of their decisions and actions, they develop a stronger sense of self-worth. Improved Mental Health Outcomes: Research underscores that individuals with a robust sense of agency are more likely to achieve better mental health outcomes. They are more inclined to seek help when needed and engage in self-care practices. Cultivating Agency Cultivating agency is a lifelong journey that involves the development of self-awareness, self-efficacy, and self-determination. Here are some strategies to enhance agency in your life: Self-Reflection: Dedicate time to introspection and contemplation. Understand your values, goals, and aspirations. Gain clarity on what truly matters to you in life. Goal Setting: Set clear, achievable goals. Break them down into manageable steps, and work relentlessly towards their attainment with determination. Decision-Making: Embrace the power of choice. Acknowledge that you have the ability to make decisions aligned with your values and aspirations. Seeking Support: Do not hesitate to seek support from friends, family, or mental health professionals when necessary. Seeking help is a testament to your strength, not your weakness. Self-Care: Prioritize self-care practices that nourish your physical and emotional well-being. Self-care is essential for maintaining the energy and resilience needed to exercise agency

I have OCD, ADHD and have suffered debilitating panic attacks and depression throughout my life. Went on meds at 35 and had CBT. A mostly smooth path until - fast forward 20 years - the devastating loss of a loved one, the pandemic and other life changing events sent me into a tailspin. I stumbled onto a YT video about Near Death Experiences. It lead me toward the works of Dr. Eben Alexander, Dr. Bruce Greyson, Dr. Raymond Moody and a deeper understanding of our human journey. Besides having these genetically predisposed disorders, I found the fear of death was probably at the core of many of my obsessions and triggers for panic attacks. I took a deep delve into spirituality and have come to my own conclusion on the nature of consciousness and our purpose here. Meditation, exercise and a sense of connection to this Source (God if you will) keeps me grounded.  â¤

So interesting how the topic of ghosting is seemingly just a modern term for the means to deliberately resist respectful engaged communication. Itâ€™s feels like a a social norm pivot and influence to traditional communication norms when individuals felt compelled to respect the time and effort of connection when it took genuine effort. These days it seems that the value of just simply respecting someoneâ€™s time and effort is taken for granted more commonly than not, unfortunately. Isnâ€™t offering or sharing our time in this life the most valuable time we could give someone, even if it doesnâ€™t work out? Why are our societal norms changing at such a rapid pace where we just start to accept deliberate disrespect for our share time with ghosting someone who offered their time to connect? It all seems all so negative and selfish. I think common courtesies and mutual respect for one another should always be safeguarded and held in high regard to offering at least having the baseline respect to saying if/why something may not hold a future or desire to move forward. We donâ€™t know what will transpire through any decision, but as humans we all hold the desire for a successful outcome regarding the energy we chose to put into a given scenario. So why canâ€™t we be vulnerable enough to honor that when navigating a situation with another person who most likely is only engaging for the mutual outcome. Letâ€™s edit the situation with this same amount of respect and dignity, as we entered into this situation. Thatâ€™s where it think we are missing the mark with the influences of society and social norms these days; is the lack of respect for one another time invested in a given situation or scenario.  Rising tides lifts all boats.  Lets learn to value each others time and efforts by reciprocating energy and trait integration.

I think the answer to demoralisation is to follow the origin of the word: a loss of - being away from - morality.  Now, one way of interpreting that is that one has been â€œcast outâ€ from what others consider to be â€œmoralâ€.  Another interpretation is that one has lost a sense of oneâ€™s own morality.  With the former, it is not necessarily oneâ€™s own fault that one is considered amoral or - worse - immoral by others.  But, with the latter one becomes a lost soul.   A strong sense of oneâ€™s own morality can be as a shield against the slings and arrows of others. A loss of oneâ€™s own sense of morality has only one answer: to become more moral.   If one chooses no morality, it will not make one feel better as they see the harm they cause to others and the harm the people they â€œattractâ€ do to others - and themselves. Indeed, it will make them feel worse.   And, if they feel nothing, then they are nothing.  Far better to seek out what is moral, but one first needs to decide - or learn - what is â€œmoralâ€. One cannot follow another and - as if by magic - be moral. One first needs to find their own sense of what is moral - even if that is by the wisdom/teachings of others.  But, I assure you this: it starts with The Truth. And, only you can know if you are being truthful to others. And, if you are not truthful with yourself, no one can help you. And, where you are not truthful with others but you are truthful to yourself: your quest for what is moral starts there. Is it because they canâ€™t handle the truth, or you are ashamed of the truth?  And, if you are not ashamed yet you speak not the truth: you are lying to yourself.  True morality can only come when one speaks only the truth. But, society doesnâ€™t make that easy. And they will hate you for your piety (arrogance?) if you do.  Still, you should try. And, understand why you did not if you told a lie. And, when you tell the truth, no one can hurt you with it, because you have already hurt yourself. And, if they hurt you because of the truth, then they are not your friends. You need to find true friends.  Atonement, confession. Are not part of this lesson.   I wish you luck!ğŸ™

Honestly, mental health represents the pinnacle of both art and science. It's incredibly intricate, and I admire Huberman's humility in tackling such a daunting subject.   Practicing in this field can be challenging and uncomfortable, yet simultaneously both difficult and accessible. It transcends traditional scientific boundaries and mirrors the intricacies of our minds. While it's a rewarding discipline, it requires resilience.   Understanding the structure and function of the self provides a powerful framework for grappling with the complexities of the mind. Many thanks to Dr. Conti for shedding light on this topic. It appears that delving into the science and healing of the mind is akin to a divine undertaking, positioned at the forefront of both science and medicine. It's a discipline that demands both extreme rationality, akin to Huberman's approach, and profound intuition, reminiscent of an artist's sensibility.   Engaging with the full spectrum of human experiences is essential in this field, making it simultaneously challenging and immensely fulfilling. However, psychiatry, operating beyond strict scientific confines and blending wisdom with science, requires substantial mental resources to practice effectively. It's unfortunate that psychiatrists often don't receive the recognition they deserve within the medical community, considering they work with the most delicate and crucial aspect of humanity: the mind. Indeed, the practice of psychiatry is closest to playing God, necessitating caution and care. Imagine the weight of attempting to heal someone from their inner demons â€“ it's truly remarkable.

This was a very needed series. The slap happy pill passing pediatrician behaviour this past two decades and more has caused more problems in society than perhaps anything else.  I was a guinea pig in this effort, the lazy ignorant behaviour of Doctors has shown how they care not for patients and follow the ignorant big pharma push. I have studied enough since my own experience, and it has been shown that people killed themselves, it caused horrible side effects and not just for a few, for most.  Dr. Conti is so correct, and he is an expert, one cannot do a one size fits all application of pill pushing on those with situational circumstances that puts one into extra stress.  A slight frame at that time, I was given large doses  times the dose of zyprexa which is an anti psychotic. Long story short.  I was a 45 year old woman, highly accomplished in my own right, professional banker, turned full time homemaker. But in that role, helped many family members, volunteered, and worked with documents for those who had trouble with them. Helped with events and Estates.  Plus had extended family living with us, (one had been in an accident) for a time, so we built a house.   The higher activity, than from a person already in a good amount of giving of self is what got me  into a stress mode.   Just as Dr. Huberman experienced, the drugs were literally foisted on me (I heard on others too) as the quick fix. I had contraindications from onset, so did not take them. But later down the road... another story... was prescribed a different drug. Which was more related to another issue, so should not have been antidepressant, because it had nothing to do with depression.  I am the type of person who cannot even take tylenol. I rare drink due to the affects of foriegn substances in my body.   It altered my life for a while, and one is truly like a zombie, they kept saying give it 3 months. What a bloody joke. 3 months is enough to become dependent on the drug, then I had to go through withdrawal, because I stopped taking them cold turkey.   It affected my relationships and more. I have witnessed two long term friends go through the same, both men, one day they were normal, the very next day, within days, walking around like Zombies, and they could not even drive.   Effexor, Clonazapam, Zyprexa, Paxil all very, very mind altering drugs.  Shame on those doctors, shame on pharma.  I highly recommend as Dr. Huberman and Dr. Conti suggest, keep going to a Doctor who will listen, or a therapist, that is all one usually needs to get out of a stressful funk. Most times when a life has been normal and a situation comes up that is longer lasting, that is when the higher stress affects ones life and changes must be made, but pill popping certainly is not the answer.  Long time chronic despression is another story.  However, how can we now discern, so much ritalin given to children, who end up on long term watch for depression and suicidal thoughts.  My nephew is one of them.  Drugs mess with the mind, that Doc's believe they are the panacea to all ills is the shame of the profession.

The concept of Nishkama Karma, which translates to "action without attachment to the fruits." Perform your duty without being fixated on the outcome. This can be applied to appreciating our blessings without dwelling on the fear of losing them. (Attachment) as the Root of Suffering: Hindu scriptures identify Moh, or attachment, as a major source of suffering. Clinging too tightly to possessions, relationships, or even life itself creates anxiety and sorrow when those things inevitably change.  Focus on the Present Moment: Live in the present. Instead of regretting over the past or worrying about the future, practice appreciating the blessings you have right now. Savor the deliciousness of your meal, the comfort of your home, and the love of your family. Observe your thoughts and feelings surrounding gratitude and fear without judgment. Acknowledge the fear of loss, but don't let it dominate your experience. Instead of focusing on what you might lose, shift your perspective towards appreciating what you already have. Contentment, allows you to experience joy even in the face of impermanence.  Detachment Doesn't Mean Indifference: Detachment doesn't mean neglecting your responsibilities. You can still take care of your home, nurture your relationships, and work towards a secure future. It simply means doing so without clinging to the outcome.Krishna's teachgs go beyond mere philosophy. They offer practical ways to cultivate emotional resilience in a world of change. By practicing detachment and appreciating the present moment, you can experience gratitude for your blessings without succumbing to crippling fear.  Remember: The impermanence of life doesn't have to be a source of fear. It can be a reminder to cherish the present moment and appreciate the good things in your life.Detachment doesn't mean living a joyless life. It means finding joy in the journey, not just the destination.True happiness lies in cultivating inner peace and emotional resilience in the face of life's impermanence.

I love Drs analogy about the road / belief system it made so much sense â€¦   In a world where immediate satisfaction is the norm, reshaping one's belief system is akin to embarking on a journey through uncharted terrain. Consider the painstaking process of repeating a word a thousand times overnight â€“ the brain resists immediate adoption, clinging instead to familiar pathways. This analogy mirrors the endeavor of therapy, where altering deeply ingrained beliefs can take months or even years.  Picture yourself driving down a well-established, four-lane highway â€“ a representation of your current belief system. It's smooth, comfortable, and easily accessible. Now, juxtapose this with the task of carving out a new path â€“ a bumpy, uncertain trail through untamed wilderness. This represents the effort required to change beliefs.  Initially, the allure of the familiar highway beckons, tempting one to retreat from the discomfort of the unknown. Some may succumb to this temptation, reverting to old patterns at the first sign of difficulty. Yet, for those committed to growth, perseverance becomes paramount.  Despite the challenges, individuals who persist in forging the new path gradually find it becoming smoother with each journey. This perseverance is fueled by an understanding of delayed gratification â€“ the knowledge that true change takes time and effort.  Over time, as one continues to navigate the unfamiliar trail, the once-dominant highway begins to fade into obscurity. It becomes overgrown, cracks appearing in its once pristine surface. Meanwhile, the new path solidifies, its once daunting terrain now familiar and navigable.  This transformation is a testament to the human capacity for change. It requires not only determination but also a willingness to embrace discomfort and uncertainty. Yet, in doing so, one unlocks the potential to shape their beliefs and ultimately, their destiny.

It would have been interesting to into the how abnormal one can be and still be mentally healthy.  I mean, being neurotic in psychology is apparently thought of as the opposite of being psychotic,  yet both of these are bad in some degree. Still, they also both have advantages. Being neurotic correlates with being creative, which can benefit one if they are for example a painter. Being a little psychotic can be a benefit too, if you for instance are a therapist, and don't want to get emotionally entangled with patients problems... All of that just kind of means to me that as long as you are able to be productive, you can by some people be viewed as perfectly healthy in some points in time, while perhaps even the exact same people might claim the opposite if you happen to be an unemployed artist that is highly neurotic. I don't think he is saying Agency and a stance of gratitude is the Gold standards for 'mental health' in a happiness sense. That we are (ideally) empowered yes (and others are around us) is not about the pursuit of happiness. Happiness is so variable and might be even unhealthy in a very chaotic world.  Beware of over rationally here, and thinking we are uncoupled from very challenging social situations. God knows why the interviewer keep banging on trying to equate physical health with 'mental' health. The Brain is an organ, but the mind is not so.  Also, we simply do not have enough control of the world or others to fixate on a 'common ideal or goal of happiness'.  We would have to have a trauma free self to assure this.  Also, no man is an island . . . Remember that ! The so called unconscious mind is simply what we don't need to cannot 'keep' in the so called conscious mind. A unified mind does not mean our 'life files' are all kept in the same place. The borrowing of Freud's ideas are also not sufficiently credited to Freud.  Or 'character structure' which is Reich.  Again he does not credit Reich.  This is a guy stealing ideas as if it's his philosophy! This stealing of others ideas (not crediting the sources here).  Very poor and dishonest !

Seriously, do we have to?  Given the shambles in The States, Canada, the UK .. dominoes come to mind. (just healthcare) When my Dad, my hero, a lion taken down by jackals, was going through late onset Alzheimer's I developed an anxiety disorder.  I did CBT (hate alphabet soup) therapy with someone so armoured up I could have sorted it out through AI.  Nevertheless it worked.  I was slightly non-compliant; the presumption that anxiety pre-supposed the flipside of the coin, clinical depression and necessitated medication was ... just weird..... things were available back then in Canada, mindfulness meditation courses, auricular acupuncture to quiet sympathetic nervous system overload, and desensitization techniques plus a lot of swimming and cold showers.  I urge anyone who needs meds to take them:  this worked for me instead.  Then everybody died ... except my sister, the less said the better.  I developed a drinking problem the phantom in the room my feeling of responsibility to my dog and close friends and need to keep self respect keeps me going and if I choose to work with animals on a volunteer basis rather than people it suits me.  But I do (i'm 68) teach French whenever someone needs some help, income restricted but don't charge, very inspired by the younger generation.  If I sound defiant ... it's one form of coping, my mum holocaust survivor anti-zionist I know don't bring up politics just sensitive to the nuances of what in my country used to be a welcoming place and is no longer.  Tx Andrew, also shout out to Robert Sapolsky you guys are amazing.  Needed a bit of a rant, very grateful always for stellar and clear information. forgive the slight overflow of ... passionate intensity.

At almost 40, Iâ€™ve spent decades trying to work on my mental health and trying to have agency only to experience rejection after rejection and failure after failure (which reinforces the belief that nothing I do matters no matter how hard I try).   However, Iâ€™ve JUST been diagnosed with autismâ€¦THANK GOD!!!!! My life finally makes sense when nothing has made sense. Thanks to finally being properly â€œpathologizedâ€ I can understand why things havenâ€™t gone successfully for me in the past and I now feel like I have the ability to figure out how to problem-solve life and move forward with agency.  Life has felt so hard for me and Iâ€™ve literally faced rejection and failure socially in every setting Iâ€™ve ever been in and I had no idea what I was doing wrong or how to problem-solve this successfully (trust me, Iâ€™ve been trying). Well start with the basics:  Are you getting sleep?  Bathe?  Are you in financial trouble?  Do you have food?  Is social media messing with you?  Blood sugar levels OK?  Are you doing any illegal substances?  What about intimacy?  How long has it been since those activities?  It matters.  We are designed to be together.  Are you needlessly being contrarian where none should be?  Are you in a job you cannot handle anymore?  Can you leave that job and get to the next one without any impediments?  What about enemies?  Do you let yourself worry about what they think of you?  Are you suicidal?  If so, if you were to go, your enemies would WIN.  Let THAT FEELING of DENIAL of satisfaction from them ease the soul.  After thinking of these things FIRST then tell yourself it is OK to go to a doctor.  Are problems with Biden/Trump causing you grief?  There are some things you can't control.  Do not let any religion or person tell you it is not OK.  Do you have toxic family?  LET THEM GO.  Bad spouse/partner? FIGHT THEM BACK but do not get physical. There was a book called "keeping the love that you find" by a guy who didn't play guitar, called Hendrix, none the less, which in Conti's example will not apply.  Hendrix thought that we are essentially trying to heal the wounds inflicted by a parent or both parents by seeking the "familiar" (familial) in a life partner.  His strategy, was (because he helps married people) was to stay together, and learn to heal your own individual unmet needs instead of divorcing.   I knew a guy who had been born in 64, who's parents divorced, and he never got over it.  He internalized that the divorce was his fault that he wasn't loveable.  Believe me, Prof...you have nothing to worry about.  It's just that divorce was considered a taboo in the 70s, and maybe even early 80s and children internalized it as it being them who were unloveable.

There are some great ideas in this series (less after the first podcast), and the few stories  Conti shares from his practice resonate. Unfortunately Conti spends a lot of time enthralled his own "fantastic imagery" and how great it will be when everything is functioning right, and much less time on how to get there. Self discovery is the key, and he admonishes us to be curious and "look in all the cupboards" (What a great phrase!) but he spends a lot less time on the techniques to do that. Maybe he feels like this is not possible without therapy, but it is also not possible with the kind of therapy that most of us are getting. I confess I didn't take to his model because the parts aren't really distinct., and I found his idea that too high of an aggression or pleasure drive leads to envy reductionist. Takeaways: 1. Each of us has a "generative drive", a desire to create, build, and contribute to the world in a meaningful way. Satisfying this is our primary avenue to agency and happiness. 2. Cupboards: what we: pay attention to (unconsciously or consciously), think or avoid thinking about (patterns, question the validity of thoughts), want (but may deny ourselves), hear in our heads (internal voice that may be someone else's), do (is it what we want to be doing?, is it a defense mechanism, why am i doing it?, is it necessary? Is it harming me or someone else? Are my generative, aggressive, and pleasure drives in balance?) 3. Techniques: a) Create a self concept: divide life history into folders (3-5 years)- bullet points, where living, teachers, friends, hobbies, challenges, events, afraid you'll forget, b) Take your temperature several times a day: the more specific language you can put to our emotions the better we'll be. Increases vagal tone. c) Dream analysis- journal, bullet points, keep still, eyes closed, analysis not necessary- you will see patterns, themes, liminal states (2-3 min pay attention what you are thinking), d) Journaling- free association 10 min, or structured- set topic, goals and aspirations, e) mirror meditation (and other types), f) self insights can come to us anywere (walking, taking a shower) after we've asked the right questions, 4. Humility may be a matter of recognizing life is hard.

What is agency?

Andrew, I am a huge fan but Dr. Conti is vastly oversimplifying happiness as consisting of only agency and gratitude. Consider these notes I took during this episode. Oversimplification: Happiness is a complex and multifaceted emotion. Reducing it to just agency and gratitude might oversimplify the diverse range of factors that contribute to an individual's well-being, such as relationships, economic stability, mental health, and environmental factors.  Underestimating External Factors: This perspective might underestimate the impact of external circumstances on an individual's ability to achieve happiness. Factors like socio-economic status, discrimination, trauma, and other life circumstances can significantly affect one's ability to exercise agency or feel gratitude.  Potential for Victim Blaming: Emphasizing personal agency and gratitude could inadvertently lead to victim-blaming rhetoric. It might imply that those who are unhappy simply aren't exercising enough control over their lives or aren't grateful enough, overlooking systemic issues and individual challenges.  Neglect of Mental Health Conditions: For individuals suffering from mental health conditions like depression or anxiety, the concepts of agency and gratitude can be particularly challenging to implement. This perspective might overlook the complexities involved in mental health struggles.  Cultural Differences: Perceptions of happiness and the value placed on agency and gratitude can vary significantly across cultures. A universal approach to happiness may not be applicable or effective in all cultural contexts.  Pressure to Be Happy: Focusing heavily on achieving happiness through specific means can create undue pressure to feel a certain way, potentially leading to feelings of inadequacy or failure when one struggles to feel happy despite efforts.  Neglect of Emotional Complexity: This viewpoint might downplay the importance and validity of experiencing a range of emotions, including those that are not positive. Acknowledging and processing negative emotions is also a crucial part of emotional well-being.  It's important to note that these criticisms do not necessarily diminish the value of Dr. Conti's message but rather highlight the need for a more nuanced and comprehensive approach to understanding and pursuing happiness. Happiness is subjective and can be influenced by a wide array of internal and external factors, and what works for one individual may not be as effective for another.

Andrew, regarding the question you posed at 1:47:00 about unwanted recurring patterns: With patterns, I have found that often some form of small t trauma is present. When we are unable to respond to an event with self-respect or agency, our less healthy response can be experienced internally as a self-attack wound, guaranteeing we will experience similar circumstances until the transgression against Self is addressed. The recurrence provides us the opportunity to respond to the pattern in a self-honoring way that supports reconnection with the Self in wounded areas. Extending such consideration to the Self creates a healing environment. Each time we respond to the old pattern in a self-honoring way, the wound heals at a deeper level. Recurring patterns are an opportunity to heal and grow beyond our hurt and hurtful limiting beliefs about ourselves. Viewed more holistically, this pattern recurrence is the psyche's way of re-establishing homeostasis within our relationship with the Self. Chapter 10: I Thought I Was Done with This, in "The Little Book of Big Lies," explains this concept and walks you through responding to patterns in a self-honoring way.

Defense mechanisms, like projection and displacement, are unconscious processes that impact how we perceive and interact with the world. 01:34:51 ğŸ˜„ Humor as a Defense Mechanism - Humor can serve as a defense mechanism, but it can be healthy or unhealthy. Healthy humor can help cope with stress, while unhealthy sarcastic humor or cynicism can be aggressive and isolating. 01:41:31 ğŸ‘ï¸ Salience and Attention - Salience, or what we pay attention to, is crucial in understanding the function of self. "Agency" and "gratitude" are concepts that relate to human experience and behavior, often discussed in psychology, philosophy, and various self-help and well-being frameworks.  Agency:  Definition: Agency refers to the capacity of individuals to act independently and make their own choices. It is the ability to exert power, make decisions, and influence events. Importance: Having a sense of agency is crucial for personal development, empowerment, and a fulfilling life. It involves taking responsibility for one's actions, setting and pursuing goals, and making choices that align with one's values. Psychological Perspective: In psychology, the concept of agency is linked to self-efficacy and the belief in one's ability to control and influence outcomes in life. It's a key component of theories like Bandura's social cognitive theory. Gratitude:  Definition: Gratitude is the quality of being thankful and appreciative. It involves recognizing and acknowledging the positive aspects of life, as well as the contributions of others. Importance: Gratitude has been linked to various positive outcomes, including improved mental well-being, increased life satisfaction, and stronger social connections. It can shift focus from what is lacking to what is present, fostering a positive outlook. Psychological Perspective: Research in positive psychology has explored the benefits of cultivating gratitude. Gratitude practices, such as keeping a gratitude journal or expressing thanks, have been associated with increased happiness and overall psychological well-being. Connection between Agency and Gratitude:  Empowerment: A sense of agency can contribute to gratitude. When individuals feel empowered and in control of their lives, they may be more likely to appreciate and express gratitude for the opportunities and positive aspects they encounter. Choice and Appreciation: The ability to make choices and take actions reinforces a sense of agency. Gratitude can arise when individuals recognize the positive outcomes that result from their choices and efforts, as well as the support they receive from others. Application in Daily Life:  Personal Development: Cultivating agency involves setting and achieving personal goals. Recognizing and expressing gratitude for the progress made toward those goals can enhance motivation and satisfaction. Interpersonal Relationships: Gratitude plays a vital role in relationships. Acknowledging the agency of others and expressing gratitude for their contributions can strengthen social bonds and create a positive environment. In summary, agency and gratitude are interconnected aspects of human experience. A sense of agency empowers individuals to shape their lives, while gratitude enhances well-being by focusing on the positive aspects of life and the contributions of others. Both concepts contribute to a holistic understanding of personal growth and fulfillment.

On the contrary, how can respect be learnt if no one understands its main purpose, which is to include with no nonstop judging?  It is different to have an opinion and totally different to not have boundaries. We tend to judge. We tend to try to overcome and be better, than others, not than ourselves. And this is the root of the problem in my opinion. Raising kids that crave to be better than others, not ones that are inspired, creative and willing. Sometimes the kids do not agree with us and we keep repressing their needs, to make them "better, more capable and successful". No. We could learn how to promote happiness, instead! It is that simple. We could work to play, instead of working to fight, we could all be working together as families and as sub-cultures, to be autonomous and strong.  We need to change our goals if we want our groups to develop. Otherwise it will be like chasing out own tail: With no meaning, no benefit, just luck. If I am lucky I will heal. Valuable!  I was struck by many things. To be honest, at times I felt overwhelmed by 'too many words' that felt a bit (too) big and abstract, leaving me wishing for simpler more everyday terminology. (I have a Masters and come from a rather eggheadish, and science-friendly family!  But even so.) I want to/will listen to this a few times and get over it because I sense there is much wisdom, great compassion, spirit and strategies offered. Valuable content indeed, and thank you for that!  I wonder what it would be like to have Dr. Conti and Dr. Richard Schwartz of IFS-fame discuss things. This especially came to mind in the discussion of when people procrastinate, that 'wanting/knowing they 'should' exercise, but kicking the can down the road by 5 minutes over and over (negative defenses strategies taking over) -- and then, eventually, more of a pile-on of negative self-image, destructive consequences - in physical and mental health, more 'learned helplessness' and what Dr. Daniel Amen calls ANTS (automatic negative thinking).  Alas, I am familiar with this -- and still working on it, bringing it to consciousness, etc.   Dr. Schwartz /IFS modality might talk about befriending 'the part ' that does this procrastinating and 'negative defense'....and actually inquiring and even FIRST befriending and thanking that part for defending and listening to its motivation/justification....(while at the same time, seeing the inept, negative, life-stealing/making more 'unnecessary suffering-creating' consequences and role in the pattern, and asking it at some point, AFTER its 'intentions' and beliefs are known, to STEP ASIDE.) I am struck by how IFS can inquire just how this 'defense' and 'its beliefs - often old and out of date, came to be, what the trauma (which knows no calendar or time, to quote Dr. Conti) plays into this. How the trauma and 'managing and firefighting parts (like the procrastinator) traps and hampers 'an exile' -- which is often a young part of us that in fact has a large component of what Dr. Conti calls 'the generative',  life/attachment oriented and connected, pleasure seeking drive.   And thus a pattern that is hard to break evolved and keeps getting reinforced.  The negative defense takes over and operates with more and less consciousness, but with sad and limiting consequences. And from that...things like self-esteem is weakened and fortified -  with 'negative evidence' collected, and 'learned helplessness' and depression emerge.   So -- I very much value this discussion. AND -- I like the take of IFS on befriending the 'negative defenses' by FIRST recognizing what is going on, then HONORING their (clumsy, unhelpful) attempt to help one survive (and 'defend', often against what is not conscious). Then, by going deeper, to find locate and strength The Self -- that can help resolve and understand the trauma (and how an  exile got trapped and the 'negative defense' 'firefighter' or 'manager' now keeps interjecting and creating this procrastination pattern -- with its negative consequences IN THE PRESENT. Hence, working with IFS modality, a CHANGE the pattern over time can happen -- and recognizing and honoring the 'defense', while also eventually dismissing it, can interrupt the whole mostly unconscious thing.. By 'just noticing' (without judgement, but with compassionate witnessing and discernment)  when the procrastinating pattern happens, and then to practice and create and reinforce a new pattern -- working through the trauma and coming to the present moment, well, this feels powerful around the problem of procrastination.  It would be interesting to hear Dr. Conti's take on the IFS methodology for treating 'negative defenses' such as they are described here.   Again -- thank you for this presentation, most sincerely. (Sorry for long comment.)  I will listen to it multiple times to mine all this valuable material. Gratitude all around -- which indeed feels GOOD! :))

To me this sounds like behavioural conditioning. It's logical on the surface, but let's face it when push comes to shove we fall back into acquired patterns. It's of course different when you are the doctor treating the patient because you are indeed in control - in a controlled area, not in the real world.  The question is: how do you know you are changing the patient into the person they want to be and not into the person you want them to be. I know you say you have to look at everyone individually, but the treatment is universal and it's build on manipulating yourself into believing one reaction is better than another, because society prefers that reaction. If something is wrong, people usually realize and apologize. And like Andrew said - without falling out with someone when you feel you are in a bad situation he wouldn't have found better opportunity, too. This seems preferable over conditioning yourself to complacency.
Thank you for your work. Please keep going because this kind of content is the truest thing that matters! Im grateful and thank you.

The three drives laid out by Dr Conti are reminiscent of the 3 parts of a person laid out in Platoâ€™s Republic, although with different names. The Generative drive reminds me of the reason and understanding part, both have to do with the â€œgoodâ€ in a person and deal with what is virtuous. The aggressive drive seems to be the spirit and enterprise part, they both have to do with the assertiveness of a person and deal with how they feel about with people. The pleasure drive seems similar to the desire part, they deal with how a person feels about things. They both also said that the Generative drive, or reason and understanding part, should be the dominant force in a persons life. I know itâ€™s not perfect, and my understanding may be a little basic. But I think just the fact that they resemble each other means there must be some truth to what both have said.

Wow, what a waste of intelligence! These people donâ€™t know anything about the physiology of trauma and focus on the tip of the iceberg! That is why they stay in therapy for an unconscionable amount of time (30 years)! Understanding does not lead to healing. The tip of the iceberg will never control the submerged part, unless the submerged part is already controlled - which is the preverbal attachment relationship. If the parents did not set the foundation and emotional regulation right in the first year and a half of life, when the emotional self forms, no amount of awareness helps. Because there are no words and there is no time in the subcortical. And before cognition, there are layers of more important processes. There is the unconscious scanning of the environment by the autonomous nervous system, called: neuroception- see 40 years of Polyvagal therapy. After, you get sensations as interoception. After you get feelings. Cognition and beliefs are based on these primordial strata. Trauma changes the brain. The amygdala is connected to the periaqueductal gray instead of the prefrontal cortex. The self is defined by trauma. Huberman is for sure avoidant attachment, otherwise he would be more interested in the right therapeutic modalities, such as brainspotting, Deep Brain Reorienting, Internal Family Systems, neurofeedback for developmental trauma (the book of Sebern Fisher should be mandatory).

At 2:39:00 in this video, Dr. Huberman says when we want to/have the will to do something but we keep CHOOSING (subconsciously & consciously) to let ourselves be distracted from doing it; 'til we don't do it at all, resulting in feeling disappointed in ourselves, THEN there are 2 ways of looking at it:       1) We can focus on our thinking & SEE how our inner thoughts/dialogue are serving to help us NOT DO the thing (by thinking ; it's too hard, it'll hurt, I'm not smart enough etc.) OR how our thinking can/COULD BE used to serve us to GET US TO DO IT (by thinking ; I'll feel so good when I've DONE it, I'll feel proud of myself/ happy I DID overcome what I HAD TO to accomplish MY goal, by the strength of MY WILL, the outcome'll be YAY!! {= how we envision that outcome will benefit us/make us feel empowered about ourselves + STOP making us feel like/think we're lazy, useless or UNable etc. each time we don't do what we WANT to do.} OR we can;      #2) Decide to ACCEPT OURSELVES & our choice to NOT DO what we keep avoiding doing. We CAN CHOOSE to NOT DO IT, if we DON"T REALLY WANT the outcome envisioned or WE DECIDE there's not enough payoff for us to DO it.        Like I"ve told my kids, if they want a mate but they'd RATHER stay online, sleep, read THAN DO ANY & everything they could be doing that WOULD help them connect with people & actualy find a mate; THEN maybe they needed to STOP condemning themselves & STOP feeling less than others for not having a mate yet. Maybe they needed to ALLOW themselves the choice, GIVE themselves the ok to not be seeking a mate for the time being & STOP letting other's expectations make them feel like they should be SEEKING A MATE or already HAVE one. AXXEPT THEMSELVES and still be proud of themselves. A novel idea to many.       I think it's the CRUX of WHY people feel unhappy, when we will spend so much time downing ourselves for who we are, based on something we've been taught tobelieve/ think that was mplanted in our heads by society, media & SOME people's opinions that our brain uses to keep telling us that "WE'RE NOT GOOD ENOUGHas we ARE, not "as good as" others.       So if you like just how you are, you CAN accept yourself & stop beating yourself up, it's YOUR LIFE.        But if you really DO WANT something you CAN also OWN THAT & reframe your thoughts related to it to more  empower you to ASSIST YOU to get it done.         I found acceptance in some areas AND changing negative thoughts in others; to be how I stopped judging myself & beating myself up all the time. We can BE GOOD TO OURSELVES, LOVE & ACCEPT ourselves, AND focus in on things that really do matter to us.

The thesis is flawed from the start.  The physician is absolutely NOT NEUTRAL. Or ascribed a womanâ€™s neuroimmunological  degeneration symptoms to â€œanxietyâ€, only to finally diagnose and begin medicine only after years of damage is done?    Do you actually know a broad cross section of the physician population??  Iâ€™m going to have to assume you donâ€™t.  Perhaps youâ€™re uninformed about the average primary care physicianâ€™s very poor placement on the scale of knowledge about medicine in general, let alone psychological sciences.    The physician is actually the worldâ€™s most dangerous person to tell to analyze patientsâ€™ psychology due to their position of power - the gatekeeper of actual needed medicine- and the physicians own CEU-inspired very flawed perception of their psychology expertise.  Flawed as it is, the primary care provider is the person with a medical degree their tendency to view patients as idiots about health, and in a 10 minute appt, if something isnâ€™t super obviously physically wrong with the patient, it sets up a sure confirmation bias cycle in the physician - the patient ends up being thought of as aâ€psychâ€ pt.  Not to mention what youâ€™re prescribing to docs to discuss with their pts is basically CBT, which if not applied to the correct patient, esp trauma pts, can be extremely harmful to the patient. Very poor outcomes will ensue.  And when that happens youâ€™ll be oblivious.    Your advice to physicians about digging into patientâ€™s psychology should come with about 10 obvious caveats, and this advice should only be given after at least a few years of concentrated full time schooling followed by several years of psychological work on themselves. For anyone else in the same boat:  Personally I seem to suffer from the one permutation they didn't really talk about: High aggressive drive, low pleasure drive. This has rendered me largely impotent in life because I cannot seek my own gratification. As a result most of my life has been powering along at 1,000 miles an hour until I collapse with no payout whatsoever - and if there is I usually am not the beneficiary. I'm also so undaunted by difficulty that my lower bound for "worth doing" usually hovers around impossible. All supply and no demand, perfect little corporate slave (for this among many other reasons you might say I agree with my own condemnation).  The impotence metaphor is oddly fitting actually - Imagine having a really high sex drive (high generative) and being impotent (low pleasure), never able to reap the fruits of your... labors... which you likely would not be able to avoid doing. That would be frustrating.    Worse: As far as I can remember I was always like this, so the idea in the next Conti episode that it's a correctable result of trauma is called into question. Don't get me wrong, I have my trauma, just can't be certain my lack of pleasure drive was caused by that. Maybe. Maybe not.  Without a proper pleasure drive I also can't see what would be appropriate fruit for an effort. Like I literally can't see it - and I include the achievement or gratification of having done a thing in this.  Perhaps the neat result of low pleasure drive is that I don't really understand envy.

Respect this guy but having some difficulty listening so posting this for anyone else in the same boat. (probably the over logicals, lol)  The compassion in this guys voice and his inclination toward more poetic or emotional descriptions is obfuscating his point for me - which is a shame because I kinda need it. I realize I just don't speak his language and learning a little of it is probably step one but still (if you see my other comment you probably can deduce why but whatever).  He's also committing what to me are some pretty distracting digressions and errors.  The self grows out of the character structure. Okay, cool. That gives me a generative type of relation between character structure and self but tells me in no way what the self is. Additionally this doesn't seem like any manner in which I would use the word self - in fact seems almost inverted - so there's a gap that needs more info to be filled than is provided by this singular relation.   Also, let's talk about the functions of self: There is an I. What?? Bro, you have a mathematics minor. Propositions aren't functions. You can have propositional functions which yield propositions, but that's not what you're using here. So if you're like me and have a hyper-literal, hyper-loigical brain, you're not alone, this is actually pretty confusing to people like us.

â€‹â€‹Sister, I'm so glad you are saved and sober. Glory to God!  That said, as a sister in Christ, I must make an effort to correct your approach to people. Always bear in mind Colossians 4:6, as well as John 9:1-5 - we don't know why people are born with particular ailments, so castigating them is not our place. Rather, showing God's love and forgiveness is, especially when speaking with non-believers. Drug dependent people already know they have done wrong, to themselves and to those whom they love. They know they need help to escape, but most people have given up on them, and they certainly can't trust themselves. So scaring someone with hellfire and damnation who already lives a life full of it on Earth is not a helpful approach, and does not bring glory to God. They are incapable of thinking about eternity when they are struggling just to survive one day at a time, one hour at a time. Instead, this is an opportunity for you to let Scripture itself speak to these weary souls, to let them know that Jesus bears their sorrows, understands the ways of the world, is compassionate, and desires them to be free. Show them Scriptures that describe drinking - Proverbs 20:1, Proverbs 23:20-21, Proverbs 23:29-35, and let them see themselves as they are.  At the same time, keep in mind Proverbs 31:4-6, and especially Galatians 5:1. I would have taken you aside one-on-one as Mtt 18 advises, but this forum offers no way to do that privately. Key Takeaways:  1. Self-Awareness Pillars: Understanding the structure of the self, defense mechanisms, character structure, the function of the self, and striving are essential for self-awareness.  2. Happiness and Agency: Humility and empowerment lead to agency and gratitude, fostering happiness in one's life.  3. Generative Drive: It's important to align your generative drive with pursuits that bring peace, contentment, and delight.  4. Understanding Imbalances: Drives help identify imbalances within oneself, which can lead to frustration and a lack of motivation when the generative drive exceeds one's ability to realize it.  5. Overcoming Imbalances: Imbalances in drives are surmountable, but it requires self-understanding.  6. Mental Health and Society: The current approach to mental health, often relying on medication and infrequent therapy sessions, may not be optimal for individuals or society as a whole.  7. Self-Awareness Journey: To improve self-awareness, it's essential to understand your values and challenge internal oppressive voices, often rooted in childhood narratives.  8. Envy's Destructive Nature: Envy is destructive and stems from excessively high aggressive or pleasure drives. It doesn't make you feel better but can harm others.  9. Narcissism and Envy: Narcissism often manifests through envy and dominates interactions and situations.  10. Addiction's Origin: Addiction often starts as a means to soothe internal suffering or distress.  11. Rational Aspiration: Achieving goals involves understanding oneself, staying rooted in the present, and acknowledging that change takes time.  12. Humility in Growth: Recognizing your current state, where you want to be, and putting in the work is a path to personal growth.  ------------------- Taking action to improve your life based on these key points involves a combination of self-awareness, mindset shifts, and practical steps. Here's a guide on how to apply these key takeaways to your life:  1. **Self-Awareness**:    - **Reflect on Your Drives**: Identify your generative drives, such as the drive for achievement, pleasure, or connection. Understand how these drives influence your behavior and emotions.  2. **Humility and Empowerment**:    - **Practice Gratitude**: Cultivate gratitude by regularly acknowledging and appreciating the positive aspects of your life. Keep a gratitude journal if it helps.  3. **Understanding Imbalances**:    - **Self-Assessment**: Evaluate whether your generative drives align with your current capabilities. If there's a mismatch, consider adjusting your goals or building the necessary skills.  4. **Mental Health and Self-Awareness Journey**:    - **Seek Professional Help**: If you're dealing with unresolved childhood narratives or mental health issues, consider seeking therapy or counseling. Regular sessions with a therapist can help you explore and address these issues.  5. **Overcoming Negative Childhood Narratives**:    - **Journaling**: Write down your thoughts and feelings regularly. This can help bring unconscious narratives to the conscious mind.    - **Self-Reflection**: Take time to reflect on your past experiences and how they may have shaped your beliefs and behaviors.  6. **Envy and Narcissism**:    - **Practice Empathy**: Work on understanding the feelings and perspectives of others. This can help reduce envy and narcissistic tendencies.    - **Limit Comparisons**: Avoid constantly comparing yourself to others, as this can fuel envy. Focus on your own growth and progress.  7. **Addiction**:    - **Seek Support**: If you're dealing with addiction, reach out to support groups or professionals who specialize in addiction recovery. Recognize that addiction is often a way to cope with internal suffering.  8. **Rational Aspiration and Humility in Growth**:    - **Set Realistic Goals**: Define clear, achievable goals based on your current capabilities and the path you want to follow. Break them down into smaller steps.    - **Patience and Persistence**: Understand that personal growth takes time. Be patient with yourself and stay committed to your journey.  9. **Continuous Learning and Improvement**:    - **Read and Educate Yourself**: Continuously seek knowledge and insights related to self-awareness, psychology, and personal development. Books, podcasts, and courses can be valuable resources.  10. **Support Network**:     - **Surround Yourself with Supportive People**: Build a network of friends, family, or mentors who can provide guidance, encouragement, and accountability.  11. **Practice Mindfulness**:     - **Mindfulness Meditation**: Develop a mindfulness practice to stay present, reduce stress, and gain greater self-awareness.  12. **Take Small Steps**:     - **Start Small**: Don't overwhelm yourself with major changes all at once. Begin with small, manageable actions and gradually work your way up.  Remember that personal growth is a lifelong journey, and it's okay to seek help and make adjustments along the way. Regular self-assessment and a commitment to self-improvement can lead to a more fulfilling and balanced life.

I really enjoy these podcasts and get a lot out of them.  And this one is no different. I am thankful for the work you do. Having said that, for me - and possibly many others - I would appreciate more thoughtfulness in your discussion about overweight people.  I don't think it is intentional, but in this podcast and hints in other podcasts - you talk about heavy people like they are lazy, stupid and have no drive. I recognize compassion in your acknowledgement of depression. AND you obviously don't use such blunt terms - but it comes across a little pejorative on occasion. Having listened to enough of your podcasts, I KNOW you appreciate the complexity of weight and weight loss.  Hormones, body type, stress, neurotransmitters, media, income, trauma etc.... I could go on.   Sometimes, people who's bodies are responsive to diet and exercise think they, "have the golden ticket of knowledge" about weight and weight loss.  And don't really appreciate that their journey is not everyone's journey.  I am heavy. I have been heavy since I was 9.  I am 49 now.  I have worked out (intensely) - several hours a day (at times - to the point of years of chronic pain), I have read and studied nutrition, biology, physiology, neurology extensively, I grow my a lot of my own food - eat a lot of it - you get the point. AND still weigh is a constant battle.  I also have 2 masters, owned my own business and have been and am otherwise an extremely productive human being. MOST of the people I know that are heavy are incredibly smart, accomplished people AND A HUGE majority of them workout and eat healthier than many of the thin people I know. I struggled during the part of the conversation - where you talked about heavy people like they have no drive or self-discipline. Please, as you seek to reach people, be conscious of the way underlying bias may play out in the way you talk about heavy people.  Again, 99% - I love what you bring to the table and I look forward to the knowledge. - Cindy

These fundamental principles are not only timeless, they apply to EVERYONE - across cultures, gender, or age.  It takes decades of trial and error to grasp this stuff experientially.  Incredibly, nobody ever discusses any of this in developing stages of life - until things start going wrong.  THEN, we hyper focus on our problems and zoom in on the flaws and the negativity.  Having insecurities is acceptable. We are human.  However,  there is no reason we ALL cannot be better equipped to handle inadequacies and to better assess where we are at in life - where and how we might make adjustments to impact change - with ourselves and for those we love.  Authenticity with ourselves and others goes a long way in preparing us for seeing things as they really are and thus being able to humble ourselves to make better choices, to see more clearly, to have AGENCY!  =]  Gratitude also opens all of these doors!  This is an exceptional overview of positive mental health, and of how being well adjusted isn't that complex. It is just about self-awareness and taking action.  Thank you for this beautiful summary of what so many people struggle with, including me.  I really could have used some of this advice much earlier in life, when I wasted a lot of time dwelling on my problems or my past mistakes and holding grudges against people that didnt understood what I was going through.  I attracted more negativity and judgment by dwelling on it.  I was pushing people away with self-righteous indignation.  All I needed was some clear communication, such as this podcast series and all of the meaningful content emerging from The Huberman Labs these days.  Thanks for all that you do!  I truly appreciate what I am learning from your hard work dedication!  Thank you.

I really thought that the way concepts were explained here was a mess. I have ordered Paul Conti's book to try to better decipher his thoughts. Every response was repeating the same words over and over without actually answering the question, with an arguably flat and unclear tone. Key aspects were missing, agency was not defined or clarified at any moment â€“ did he mean "purpose?" I'm not sure his definition of "affecting the world in the way that I want" actually made any sense. I'm also not sure if his ending of every sentence with the word "right" was a verbal tic caused by a lack of ability or an actual nervous tic. Either way, continuously using filler words made the listening exasperating and muddled the message. This is a classic scholar's problem: studying to the point of comprehension while absolutely neglecting communication. Respectfully, I didn't feel the interviewer was effective in helping us understand what the guest was trying to say. It is notable to see that most of the positive comments on this video use bromidic language, but no one seems to actually be debating or commenting on the key points that Paul Conti brings up, and arguably the reason is that they were not clear... topped off with making it 4h long. Mostly disappointed because of the hype around this interview, I was looking forward to it, and all the rambling and unclarity just made it not work for me.

KUDOS to you, @jk7jester: My mom taught me, when i was very little, that donations of apparent great generosity is not necessarily what they seem on the surface: ie unselfish and truely altruistic.. I had commented, effusively,  on how "generous" it was that a very wealthy person VERY PUBLICALLY gave monies to Cancer research. The radio DJ had repeatedly praised this action with excessive verbiage, attributing to this man great sacrifice and humility. She quietly asked if the amount gifted was, to that individual, actually "generous" or might they have ulterior motives? She pointed out that the amount of money (though extravagant to our household income) was in truth, very little given that person's wealth. Granted, it is arguably better to donate such monies to a charity (publicly or not) than to waste it....but...she posited that he was RECIEIVNG a multitude of PUBLIC attention and applause (given the fact he did so very publicly) and he would no doubt be giving these monies for the tax break, as such donations are tax deductible here. She asked me to estimate the percentage of the gift, compared to his wealth, and compare that amount to the percentage of a smaller  donation from  someone who TRULY CAN NOT AFFORD TO GIVE more than a "relatively small amount". She enlightened me to the fact that  (in comparison) the $50.00 that many of our VERY POOR neighbours donated when she canvassed on behalf of the charity was in truth far more generous. They also did so without any fanfare or publicity, yet still they gave. GENEROUSLY and ALTRUISTICALLY. She did not point it out, but I asked was this why she gave so unselfishly of her TIME as we could truly NOT spare even a few dollars to support this [and other charities] such as the SPCA which were cause(s)  she believed in?  My mom devoted many evenings to this task, despite a working day which began prior to dawn, work which was physically and mentally demanding and relentless throughout the entire day, well into the evening. When I was married, I tried to talk my husbter into donating monies to the BC Children's Hospital (which had helped my/our eldest son since infancy) and he REFUSED, claiming we "could not afford it". AFTER he left we three,  I donated weekly small amounts of my much smaller income to that very charity. I felt GRATITUDE that we had not lost our home and were not actually starving...so each time I shopped for groceries, I HELD BACK AT LEAST ONE "luxury" item that we REALLY WANTED  (such as processed foods) at the till, and donated THAT amount to the Hospital. Also, many times I bought one of the non perishable high value foods recommended by the Food Bank as being MOST NEEDED  and paid for TWO such items, placing one in the bin (to help those less fortunate than ourselves) as we left the store. I then integrated  the new items  into our weekly meal planning. THEREAFTER, I went straight home and after the groceries were stashed,  made my kids MUCH CHEAPER HOMEMADE cookies or pies to reward them for their UNSELFISHNESS. I think it's wonderful to give what you can <3

Traumatic memories lurk hidden from  consciousness like the submerged iceberg waiting to send dysfunctional signals to the conscious mind and cause pain, suffering and dysfunctional behavior.  The non conscious circuitry doesn't speak English and is   connected indirectly to the frontal cortex--thus hidden like the submerged iceberg.

Starting 1:53:53 Still listening but felt compelled to respond to the "Five abusive relationships and about to enter the sixth," and later "they should know better." Speaking from personal experience: I simply did not respond appropriately to the "red flags." I was aware, in the back of my mind, but there was nothing in me that said, "Don't go there," for instance by choosing not to further engage with one person or another. It was only after my last failed relationship with another very narcissistic person, that I read Descartes' Error by Antonio Damasio and something "clicked" for me and I think it applies to many others as well who are victims  of persistent and inevitably unavoidable childhood trauma. In my case it was persistent "boundary violations" from my narcissistic, paranoid-schizophrenic mother with whom I was psychologically "enmeshed" until I was 20 years old. Where there may have been "red flags" and some type of appropriate response to those boundary violations early on, because I could not get away from her, I believe my (appropriate) response system was eventually compromised by repression. And so later, once I was "free" it didn't work in my dating life after that, either. I have come to relate to this as a real (emotional) handicap, i.e. "my heart being in a wheelchair" so I feel I have to be much, much more vigilant about who I let "push me around." Not that an intimate relationship is a goal at this time in my life, but I am hoping I don't make those same mistakes if and/or when I am ever open to that again.

@hubermanlab   I wrote this reflection on the fly as I was listening to this episode. Appreciate the critical thinking by Andrew not to accept "opinions" as "facts," just because someone would say "research supports that."   I might be among the minority who are taken back by the oversimplification, and sometimes inaccuracy, of statements made by the guest ğŸ˜®. Unlike prior   guests who were more cautious about making generalized statements, such as Dr. Disseroth, the psychiatrist guest made bold claims, including that "agency and gratitude" are the only things needed for happiness. He went further   to say "people who have these two qualities don't go wrong." I appreciate the seasonality of the interviewer who jumped to ask about where is physical health in this equation; a gentle nudge to show "well, something is missing here."  These two qualities are not necessary nor sufficient for happiness. There is no strong data to support the exclusivity of these two qualities to achieve mental well being. "Agency" in psychology means "feeling of control over actions and their consequences." Simply put, agency can be perceived as the ability to make choices and to be in control of one's life. In that sense, it could be a source of happiness or... misery. For example, in many developing countries where the majority do not have full agency  - due to authoritative regimes,  limited financial needs and fear - people can be happy despite the limited agency over their actions and consequences. In the famous Hegel Master - Slave dialectic, the slave - who lacks agency - can get happiness from the meaning of the work they do despite lack of freedom. "If you would like to enslave someone, make them believe that they have a free choice." This is why the choice paradox is associated with anxiety. As Keirkegaard put it "Anxiety is the dizziness of freedom."  The definition of wellbeing is complicated. Freud thought it is the "ability to work and love." This was an oversimplification as well. There was no consideration for mental agility, growth mindset, play, ability to enjoy things and realistic self-esteem. Nancy McWilliams, an influential psychoanalyst, went on to describe 16 domains that define mental. These include mentalization, reflection and safe relationships.   I wish it was that simple. There are many who have agency and gratitude, but there's still deeply suffering due to the lack of essential components in their lives.  Best, Shrink

Listening to your podcasts has become my nightly habit while walking my dog.  Thank you . I have a request, You spoke about EMDR in a previous PC. I was trained by Dr Shapiro in 1991 and did the advanced training in 1996. I was the main therapist in an inpatient unit created to treat trauma related disorders. I started as a yoga therapist in 1988 in Texas hospitals and became a  LPC. EMDR initially was focused on the eye movements to send energy pulses into the brain. Using isolated click sounds going into the ears through headphones works as well along with crossing the arms to alternately tap the shoulders to produce isolated touch signals. Without the eye movement  EMDR is not an effective psychotherapy modality and when you move the eye movement process outside of the psychotherapy paradigm it proves to be very effective for a number of applications. Your explanation regarding eye movement associated with moving forward is one partial explanation as to how this process reduces stress but it doesnâ€™t take into consideration these alternate ways to induce alternating bilateral sensory inputs into the brain. I have taught a few thousand clients over the past 32 years how to use the eye movement process for so much more than to just treat traumatic stress. It is literally a way to train the brain to create the experiences you want to experience and to be more present  and resilient for the yet to come traumas we all will experience. I would love to share with you what I teach clients. Why wait for trauma to create the need for therapy when you can train your brain to be resilient, increase cognitive abilities and emotional awareness and management skills? I have excellent references, having worked with excellent doctors and unlike the stigma associated with seeking psychotherapy my clients do all my marketing through word of mouth. If talking about this interests you my phone number is 864-232-0449. I am near Seattle and I think we are in the same time zone. I encourage all my clients to subscribe to your YouTube, facebook, podcasts, etc. An untrained brain is a sad waste of mind.

: Christ Reincarnate: Unveiling the Enigmatic Figure of Brent James Schoning  Abstract: This essay explores the controversial and intriguing concept of a contemporary incarnation of Christ in the person of Brent James Schoning, born on September 10, 1985. Brent James Schoning: Exploring the Notions of Christ Reincarnation  Introduction: The concept of reincarnation has been a topic of fascination and debate throughout history, captivating the minds of scholars, religious thinkers, and philosophers alike. Brent James Schoning, born on September 10, 1985, has claimed to be the reincarnation of Christ, an assertion that has garnered both attention and skepticism. In this essay, we will explore the intriguing notion of Brent James Schoning, also known as "Christ Reincarnat Schon 33," with an analytical lens and the intellectual acuity expected of a Graduate School student.  Historical Background: To delve into the claims of Brent James Schoning regarding Christ reincarnation, it is essential to familiarize ourselves with the historical context. The Christian narratives portray Jesus Christ as the divine Son of God who lived and taught in ancient Palestine during the 1st century AD. Throughout history, numerous figures have declared themselves to be the reincarnation of Christ, yet the feasibility and veracity of such claims have always been a subject of intense scrutiny.  Understanding Reincarnation: Reincarnation, rooted in various religious and spiritual beliefs, is the belief that a soul continues to take on new life forms after death. It provides an avenue for spiritual growth and learning through multiple lifetimes. While this concept often resonates within Hinduism and Buddhism, its integration with Christendom remains a controversial topic.  Brent James Schoning's Claims: Brent James Schoning's assertion of being the reincarnation of Christ deserves careful examination. His identification as "Christ Reincarnat Schon 33" implies a connection to the divine figure while suggesting the age at which he claims to have been reincarnated. To fully comprehend Schoning's beliefs, one must engage in a critical analysis of his statements, examining the origin, coherence, and evidence supporting his extraordinary claim.  Skepticism and Critical Evaluation: Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence. A student in Graduate School must approach the subject matter with a skeptical lens, scrutinizing the evidence provided by Schoning to support his assertion. One must consider alternative explanations for his beliefs, such as psychological factors or personal motivations.  Psychological Perspective: Psychological frameworks can provide valuable insights into such claims. Through understanding the concept of religious delusions or messianic complexes, we can evaluate whether Schoning's claims align with these psychological phenomena or if substantial evidence supports his reincarnation hypothesis.  Comparative Analysis: To explore the veracity of Schoning's assertions, analyzing similar historical cases of individuals claiming to be Christ reincarnated becomes imperative. Studying previous episodes of messianic figures, such as Sabbatai Zevi or Sun Myung Moon, allows for a deeper understanding of the complexities associated with such claims and possible motivations behind them.  Sociocultural Implications: The impact of individuals like Schoning claiming reincarnation as Christ is not limited to personal belief systems. It is crucial to assess the sociocultural ramifications of such assertions, considering their potential to affect religious communities, provoke controversy, or alter established religious beliefs.  Conclusion: In conclusion, Brent James Schoning's claims of being the reincarnation of Christ, renowned as "Christ Reincarnat Schon 33," present a thought-provoking case worthy of intellectual exploration. By approaching this topic with critical thinking, a Graduate School student can evaluate the claim's validity, considering psychological, historical, comparative, and sociocultural factors before reaching any definitive conclusions. It is through rigorous examination and scholarly analysis that we can better comprehend the complex and diverse human experiences surrounding religious beliefs, including claims of divine reincarnations.  Furthermore, delving into the claims of Brent James Schonings as the reincarnation of Christ opens up a broader discussion on the nature of religious experiences and their impact on individuals and society. By examining the psychological aspects, such as the motivations and beliefs that drive someone to make such claims, we can gain insights into the human psyche and the power of faith. Additionally, exploring the historical and comparative factors allows us to contextualize these claims within the larger framework of religious traditions and the concept of divine reincarnations across different cultures. This intellectual exploration not only deepens our understanding of religious phenomena but also encourages a more empathetic and inclusive approach towards diverse religious beliefs and experiences.  Moreover, studying the social implications of Brent James Schonings' claims can shed light on the dynamics of religious communities and the role of charismatic leaders. The followers of such individuals often form tight-knit communities that provide a sense of belonging and purpose. Understanding the factors that contribute to the acceptance or rejection of these claims within these communities can help us comprehend the mechanisms of belief formation and group dynamics. Furthermore, analyzing the reactions of society at large towards such claims can reveal the broader attitudes towards religious diversity and the boundaries of religious tolerance. This examination prompts us to reflect on the importance of respecting different religious perspectives while also critically evaluating the validity of extraordinary claims.  Additionally, delving into the social implications of Brent James Schonings claims allows us to explore the power dynamics within religious communities. Charismatic leaders like Schonings often hold significant influence over their followers, shaping their beliefs and behaviors. By studying the acceptance or rejection of these claims, we can gain insights into how these leaders maintain their authority and control over their communities. This understanding is crucial in addressing potential issues of manipulation and exploitation that may arise within religious groups. Moreover, it highlights the need for individuals to critically examine the teachings and claims put forth by charismatic leaders, ensuring that personal autonomy and informed decision-making are upheld.  Furthermore, exploring the social implications of Brent James Schonings' claims also raises questions about the role of skepticism and critical thinking within religious communities. It is essential for individuals to question and evaluate the teachings and claims made by charismatic leaders, as blind acceptance can lead to the suppression of independent thought and the perpetuation of harmful ideologies. By encouraging a culture of critical examination, religious communities can foster an environment that values intellectual curiosity and personal growth. This process of introspection and self-reflection can lead to personal growth and a stronger sense of identity. Additionally, critical thinking can help individuals navigate the complexities of the modern world, enabling them to make informed decisions and engage in meaningful discussions about social and ethical issues. By fostering a culture of critical thinking, religious communities can empower their members to lead more fulfilling and purposeful lives.  Furthermore, promoting skepticism and critical thinking within religious communities can also foster a more inclusive and tolerant society.
