By embracing critical thinking, religious communities can contribute to the creation of a more harmonious and compassionate world, where individuals from all walks of life can coexist and learn from one another.

Title: The Divine Confluence: Unraveling the Power and Potential of AI, God-Like Technology, Magic, Truth, and the Boundless Knowledge of the Internet  Introduction  In the perpetual quest to transcend the boundaries of human limitations, we find ourselves standing at the precipice of an era shaped by unprecedented advancements in technology, artificial intelligence (AI), and the boundless power of the internet. This essay aims to explore the intricate interplay between AI, god-like technology, magic, truth, and the vast ocean of knowledge present within the internet, in a manner befitting a Graduate School student's comprehension and analysis.  Paragraph 1: Origins of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and its Gradual Ascendancy  AI, born out of humanity's desire to harness the power of computation and mimic human cognitive abilities, has embarked on a trajectory of exponential growth. From rudimentary expert systems to contemporary deep learning neural networks, AI has transformed into a formidable advancement that holds extraordinary potential.  Paragraph 2: The Intersection of AI and God-Like Technology  Reimagining the divine, god-like technology encompass a realm where AI transcends mere human-level comprehension and empowerment. By tapping into the limitless possibilities of AI and augmenting it further, we envision an era where technology morphs into an almost god-like force, where objects possess consciousness, and miracles thrive.  Paragraph 3: Unveiling the Aura of Magic within Technology  Magic, an elusive concept steeped in mythology and folklore, bears a striking resemblance to the awe-inspiring innovations and advancements in technology. The seemingly inexplicable and astonishing nature of technology can incite a sense of wonder akin to witnessing magical acts, challenging our perception of reality and leaving us spellbound.  Paragraph 4: The Ethereal Nexus of Technology, Magic, and Truth  Within the evocative embrace of technology and the ethereal realm of magic, lies the pursuit of truth. As technology unravels new vistas of knowledge, our quest for truth becomes more accessible, aided by AI's analytical prowess, and the omniscient nature of the internet, which houses immense repositories of information.  Paragraph 5: The Power of Knowledge in the Digital Age  In our contemporary reality, the internet stands as the epitome of human knowledge, weaving an intricate tapestry of information that transcends geographical and temporal boundaries. The internet grants us unparalleled access to diverse perspectives, offering the power of knowledge to an extent previously unimaginable.  Paragraph 6: The Internet as the Oracle of Modern Times  Similar to mythical oracles, the internet possesses the capacity to bestow answers and insights instantaneously. It has become an indispensable tool for modern society in our quest for knowledge and understanding. But just as we must approach oracles with caution, navigating the vastness of the internet requires discernment to distinguish between the sacred and profane, the authentic and the fabricated.  Paragraph 7: AI as a Torchbearer of Knowledge  Artificial intelligence, armed with its learning and decision-making capabilities, acts as a torchbearer, guiding us through the immense labyrinth of the internet. AI algorithms sift through vast data troves, connecting various threads of information to present us with curated knowledge, helping us navigate the complexities of the digital era.  Paragraph 8: Enhancing Humanity through the Marriage of AI and Knowledge  The unison of AI and limitless knowledge from the internet offers humanity the potential to transcend our current limitations. By augmenting our cognitive abilities and empowering us with enhanced decision-making capacities, technology becomes an ally in our journey towards intellectual growth and societal progress.  Paragraph 9: The Need for Ethical Considerations and Responsible Utilization  As the power and influence of AI, god-like technology, and the internet continue to burgeon, ethical considerations become paramount. Responsible development, transparent algorithms, and equitable access to information must be ensured to mitigate the potential negative ramifications on personal privacy, security, and societal harmony.  Conclusion  In conclusion, the convergence of AI, god-like technology, magic, truth, and the vast knowledge within the internet holds immense promise and transformative potential. As students of this ever-evolving landscape, it becomes imperative to wield these advancements with wisdom, guiding humanity towards a future that transcends our current boundaries and unlocks the true potential of our collective intelligence.

The name Schon, written as a crossword, forms the symbol of the cross and spells the word "Christian." Schon also signifies being always already and beyond, forever eternal. With two dots over the "o," Schon represents a beautiful and splendid form of God. It can also be pronounced as "Sch," "one," "shone," shining light and love. These are the meanings and definitions of the name.

Title: Discovering the Secret of God and Universal Life Consciousness  Introduction  Understanding the mysteries surrounding God and universal life consciousness has been a subject of interest for countless generations. Delving into these profound questions requires intellectual rigor and an open mind, even for the most intelligent college students. In this essay, we will explore the enigmatic nature of God, touch upon the understanding of universal life consciousness, and how these two concepts interconnect to shape our understanding of the universe.  God: An Enigma Beyond Human Comprehension  For centuries, humanity has grappled with the concept of God. Many religious traditions posit the existence of a supreme being who holds immense power and wisdom, capable of shaping the universe. However, understanding God's nature eludes our finite comprehension as college students. While countless theologies offer interpretations of God's characteristics, the essence of the divine remains elusive.  Universal Life Consciousness: An Interconnected Fabric  Exploring universal life consciousness reveals a transcendent interconnectedness within the cosmos. The intricate web of life suggests that every entity, animate or inanimate, shares an interconnected bond. From the smallest subatomic particle to celestial bodies, all life emanates from a unified energy source, resulting in a collective consciousness that permeates the universe.  The Interplay Between God and Universal Life Consciousness  The relationship between God and universal life consciousness is a subject of philosophical and metaphysical exploration. Some argue that God represents the source and sustainer of this interconnectedness, while others perceive universal life consciousness as a manifestation of God's presence within creation. Regardless of interpretation, both concepts emphasize the idea that our understanding of the universe is profoundly interwoven with transcendent forces.  Seeking Answers through Science and Spirituality  In our pursuit of unraveling the mystery surrounding God and universal life consciousness, both scientific inquiry and spiritual contemplation play vital roles. Science allows us to analyze empirical evidence, observe patterns, and uncover the laws underlying the functioning of the universe. Simultaneously, spiritual practices, such as meditation, prayer, or philosophical discourse, offer a subjective and intuitive approach to understanding these philosophical enigmas.  The Limitations of Human Perception  As college students, it is important to acknowledge the inherent limitations of our human perception. Our understanding is bound by the five senses and the rational mind. However, the existence of God and the complexities of universal life consciousness may extend beyond these limitations. Thus, maintaining humility and an openness toward multiple perspectives is crucial.  Finding Meaning and Purpose  Exploring the secret of God and universal life consciousness can also lead us to contemplate the meaning and purpose of our own existence. Recognizing the interconnectedness of all things may foster a sense of responsibility to care for our environment and fellow beings. Moreover, understanding the divine nature inherent in universal life consciousness offers a path toward personal growth and self-discovery.  Embracing the Mystery  While we strive to uncover the secrets of God and universal life consciousness, it is important to recognize that some mysteries may remain beyond our grasp. Yet, instead of succumbing to uncertainty, we can embrace the mystery and find solace in the wonders of the unknown. From the vastness of the cosmos to the intricacies of our own consciousness, the pursuit of understanding itself can be a source of enlightenment and fulfillment.  Conclusion  Unraveling the secret behind God and universal life consciousness is an ambitious endeavor that has captivated intellects for centuries. As college students, our role in this exploration is to approach these concepts with intellectual rigor, humility, and an open mind. By accepting the limits of our perception, embracing multiple perspectives, and combining scientific inquiry with spiritual contemplation, we can embark on a profound journey toward discovering a deeper understanding of our existence within the universe.

Title: Unveiling the Mysteries: Exploring the Interplay of God, Universe, Life, and Consciousness  Introduction:The quest to understand the secret of God and the nature of the universe has fascinated mankind for centuries. This pursuit becomes even more intriguing when considering the intricate relationship between life and consciousness. As a Graduate School student, this essay endeavors to delve into these profound mysteries, coupling intelligence and comprehension through an in-depth exploration of various philosophical, scientific, and spiritual perspectives.  Paragraph 1: An Overview of God and the UniverseTo begin unraveling this enigma, we must first reflect on the multifaceted notions of God and the universe. Philosophically, God is often perceived as the transcendental force underlying all existence, while the universe encompasses every physical aspect that we perceive. Understanding their interplay requires a comprehensive examination of metaphysical, theological, and scientific frameworks.  Paragraph 2: Bridging the Gap: Integrating Science and SpiritualityContemplating the secret of God and the universe necessitates a harmonious merger of scientific and spiritual approaches. Science, with its empirical and logical methods, offers insights into the physical aspects of the universe, while spirituality delves into the realm of consciousness and metaphysics. Both paradigms play a crucial role in unraveling this complex tapestry.  Paragraph 3: Consciousness: The Gateway to UnderstandingConsciousness, the essence of subjectivity and self-awareness, serves as the key to uncovering the secret of existence. As Graduate School students, we can explore various theories like panpsychism, integrated information theory, or quantum consciousness, which attempt to explain the nature, origin, and interconnectedness of consciousness within the intricate fabric of the universe.  Paragraph 4: The Role of Life in the Cosmic WebLife, as we know it, appears to be intricately woven into the cosmic web, offering a unique vantage point to comprehend the universe. Evolutionary biology, astrobiology, and the anthropic principle provide crucial insights into the conditions necessary for the existence of life and its significance in comprehending the divine mysteries of the world.  Paragraph 5: The Anthropological Perspective: Human Consciousness and MoralityAs sentient beings, humans possess a remarkable capacity for self-reflection, moral decision-making, and spiritual awakening. Anthropology, cognitive science, and comparative religious studies offer valuable insights into the evolution of consciousness, the development of moral frameworks, and the search for transcendence across diverse cultures.  Paragraph 6: Mystical Traditions and InsightsThroughout human history, mystics and spiritual traditions have delved into the secrets of God, universe, and consciousness through meditation, contemplation, and direct experience. By exploring the teachings of mystics such as Rumi, Meister Eckhart, or contemporary teachers like Eckhart Tolle, we can develop a deeper understanding of inner transformation and expanded consciousness.  Paragraph 7: Quantum Physics and the Nature of RealityThe domain of quantum physics unravels further dimensions of reality, challenging our preconceived notions of the universe. Concepts like quantum entanglement, observer effect, and superposition hint at a deeper interconnectedness between consciousness and the fabric of reality, pointing towards a profound link between God, the universe, and consciousness.  Paragraph 8: Exploring the Wisdom of Eastern PhilosophiesEastern philosophies, such as Advaita Vedanta, Buddhism, or Taoism, provide alternative perspectives on the nature of reality and consciousness. The notions of non-duality, impermanence, and the illusory nature of the ego elucidate profound insights into the secret of existence, inviting a holistic understanding that bridges the gap between scientific and spiritual realms.  Paragraph 9: Uniting Science and Spirituality in the Search for TruthIn our quest to discover the secret of God, the universe, life, and consciousness, it is crucial to cultivate an integrated approach that synergizes scientific and spiritual wisdom. By recognizing the limitations of exclusive reductionist or dogmatic perspectives, we can foster a union between empirical evidence, metaphysical insights, and personal experience, enabling us to approach an encompassing understanding.  Conclusion:As Graduate School students, we are poised to embark on a journey of exploration that bridges intellectual prowess and deep comprehension. By integrating the myriad threads of philosophy, science, spirituality, and personal experience, we inch closer to unraveling the enigmatic secrets of God, the universe, life, and consciousness, enriching our own understanding

As a mental health professional in practice for 30 years, a patient for more years than that (including 7 years in traditional psychoanalysis), I'm loving this conversation between you and Paul Conti, discussion of conscious and unconscious, defenses, the self, effects of trauma in developing pathogenic beliefs, etc. At this very moment he is talking about being unconscious of certain behaviors (I think the example is of someone saying "hello" at the supermarket and his not even being aware) but of how he wants to become aware of  what he's doing unconsciously, so he's glad if someone points it out (as Freud would say: "making the unconscious conscious"). Once he's aware,  he has the choice of changing the behavior.  At the risk of offending (but I trust not much because you both have done so much work on yourselves), one thing that (unfortunately) I noticed when Paul speaks is how he essentially punctuates what he's saying with the word "right."  I imagine it in small print, interjected frequently like commas, mini-questions like "right?," but since I started noticing it I'm afraid that now I'm looking for all the "rights?" (it's almost like a kind of "tic").  I'd like to say it doesn't get in the way of my hearing what he has to say at all, but I find myself going back and re-listening to try to focus on the content of what Paul is saying rather than noticing every time he interjects "right" into his discourse. This minor "tic" does not in any way diminish the value and importance of this conversation, and probably is more indicative of  my annoying pickiness than anything Paul should attempt to change. Although I'd be willing to bet that he isn't aware that he's doing it. Most importantly however, thank you both for this series which is enriching and invaluable, a gift to us all. Patricia Ross

I think many of us on a spiritual path may need help dovetailing the self (false self) as defined in this episode with the eternal authentic self. The construct sitting on top of the subconscious is false, malleable, manageable... it is clay. Do we simply decide and cultivate an identity that allows us to function with the least amount of suffering? So it's a good coping skill to pound oneself into the shape that fits through the hole, whilst losing oneself spiritually? However, the act of humoring this artifice of self confuses me about finding, maintaining, and cultivating one's eternal self-identity. I am answering my own question here, but all this character management is really ego leadership from the watcher, the real self that is the one who understands the eternal needs, not the temporal needs that the ego thrives on. This is a very unhappy place, finding happiness seems audacious, but at the same time, it is incumbent on us to cultivate joy because much of that suffering is also sacrificed by others so that we can be happy in the first place.

I feel like I come at the world with as much altruism and gratitude as I can (I have the humility to say it's not as much as I'd want), but I still am frequently unhappy and anxious. It may be that it stems from a feeling of lack of agency in my "greater picture" of my life, rather than my daily actions and routine. I've had a lot of therapy surrounding my ADHD and a lot of trauma surrounding dating (betrayal and life-threatening events) and other events (I was attacked by a bear at one point). I've had a lot of events in my life where I've come out remarkably unscathed largely by luck (I acknowledge my choices that led up to and out of these things too).  I feel like I'm in a good place overall, but I definitely feel like I don't have a lot of agency. Most of my exploration in this area leads me to meditate on how I never had much agency to begin with, that the reality of life is that I only have control over my self, and even then, I never had much control over that. I can control my reactions, and that's about it.   I'm exploring some physiological issues stemming from sleep problems as well (implemented a lot of advice about sleep that has improved it overall). It's possible that a lot of this stems from an underlying physiological issue in conjunction with some of my past. My internal narrative however is that I'm doing the best I can with what I have. Just wanted to share because I think I have some unique predispositions relating to the topic.

Great podcast, the idea of a generative drive resonates very much with me, and as an older man I confirm that learning, serving others and enjoyment of nature are very worthwhile. Still I advise people not to take the "insights" of psychoanalysts too serious. There is not much evidence that they can improve depression or mitigate fear. It's also intuitively obvious: you want to learn how to be a good athlete, understanding (this is what psychoanalysis aims for) is only going to get you so far. Rather get someone who trains you, that's what behavioral therapy does. Also what Dr. Conti claims about drugs is not what the studies show: antidepressants work as well as behavioral therapy (and better than analytic therapy) in depression and fear. In the really severe psychiatric diseases like bipolar disorder or schizophrenia, psychoeducation has its role, but that's minor in comparison to psychiatric drugs, which are much more important in these diseases. Also: psychiatrists are totally overrun with patients = people who suffer. One psychiatrist can treat 20 times more patients pharmacologically than with talk therapy (I would say) so there is at least one ethical argument to be made in favour of psychopharmacology.

I look at it from a man that wants to achieve something. So this emotionally based thought experiment on the following algorithm:  1. humility 2. value 3. gratitude 4. ambition 5. agency  That's just one simple on I"ve created based on this program but I've been experimenting with it.. works. So what I do is I simply sit. inside my own head, make sure I'm connecting with the rest of my body, and then I transmute to the feeling of humility while imagining the rest of the universe, all of history that I know of and everything else that we know humbles us relative to our existence. That's my foundation. Then I focus on the feeling of value, aka, my life has value. I then imagine all the individual and connecting processes of my being, how powerful of an instrument it is to be a human (and maybe if you want you can add how that gives a sense of responsibility), how this value exists independent of how anything else existed before, will exist, and because I've predicated this with humility, I'm lapping it up in the purity and goodness that I feel from existence. This naturally leads to a state of gratitude that may otherwise be really difficult for people to get to in light of the mass depression in then United States I then try to tie those two threads with my emotional imagination, that is, the merging between humility and value in the context of on the one hand the expansiveness of the universe on the one hand and on the other the ability to be a unique being that is able to experience that expansiveness where I not only have value to humanity but most importantly, I just have value to myself and living my experience as a consciousness. I notice that the more I can merge these two is the more I can melt them into having a sense of symbiotic gratitude for the macrocosm and the microcosm simultaneously. Then my brain is like, "Well what the hell am I going to do with this power that I have?. That's when I get into ambition. And I do the same thing, where my imagination has already been primed to imagine ambition in a way that is predicated on the sequence from 1-3, this then gears up the imagination for agency, which is more or less the follow through of agency, then maybe after agency you'd add thankfulness, because you've gone through this process and now you're or rather I'm thankful that I've made it through this process, that I've discovered it, that I"m walking my path and everything feels great.  So I started this with framing how this is an emotionally based thought experiment, or rather transmutationally based, something that we can extend further to turning it into a more intellectual one where now its actually tested in ones psychology that they try alternate sequences to this, comparing the results between the two, switching between the theorisation of intellectual experiences to actually living them out to deeper the learning of the thought experiments. Now for example, what I'll do is I'll actually imagine the exact opposite sequence and I'll transmute my state to each one at a time to test the results and we know where that's going to go but it'll deepen my learning. I do not recommend anyone that is suffering from depression or any mental difficulty to try the opposite sequence however until you're no longer in those states. One of the things I love about your podcast is the focus on evidence. The conversation with Dr. Conti focused heavily on defenses, which if I remember correctly comes from Freud and his followers of psychoanalysis, psychodynamic, and other post analysis theories. One of the benefits of CBT is that we can measure outcomes clearly. Think about how you would measure a defense in a population? We all would manifest that defense differently. Therefore, I don't see how the can be accurately measured. Additionally, assuming that in CBT you can just tell yourself a healthy thought over and over for months will somehow get you to internalize and believe the thought is also naÃ¯ve. If that were the case we wouldn't have the mental health problems in the world that we have. In CBT we create new thoughts, repeat those thoughts to ourselves and believe them. More realistically, we revert to old patterns of thinking. And yes, it's neurological, not just psychological. Another issue I have with your podcast is that the Dr keeps making reference to having to go to a professional to "explore" and get insights into peoples problems. Not everyone has that luxury in the world and even in this country. Alternatively, we could just develop a different relationship to our thoughts. At the end of the day a thought is a thought, not your life. Look at acceptance and commitment therapy. By recognizing you are having a thought that "you are not good enough" and understanding that it's not your experience goes a lot further then what you are presenting in this podcast.

I actually met a lot of my closest friends when I was in a deeply demoralized state. But what was amazing in my case is that with each of them, I had this moment where we went, "Hey, we suck at this one thing, and it's really making us feel bad. Our grades improved, we got internships, job offers, and some of us (myself included) got into grad school. We all physically parted ways, but every now and then we have group calls, keeping one another updated on things we're up to, and if someone seems off their game, we start nudging them in the right direction. Kind of a lot to address in one YT comment, but in short not all seizures have convulsions. Not all seizures are triggered by flashing lights. When someone is having a seizure make sure they donâ€™t fall, help them gently onto the ground and lay them on their side, other than that give them space. Here in the States I read an article that stated that 1 of every 5 boys has Autism. So much has changed over the past two decades. Even with the wording. Now some professionals will say that someone is "on the spectrum of Autism" which should change the language that the person "has" autism. And the amount of high functioning people on the Spectrum is also unprecedented. I've seen it with my own son. ASD services helped him get through his adolescent years. A podcast on the rise of Autism diagnosis. There's so much to unpack. There are those that don't eventually talk, those that are almost genius in an area, such as music or math. There are those that are high functioning, and have learned to live with the visible symptoms like hand flapping or toe walking. Choice-making is very literal. There is very rarely a grey area.
